timeline.bodyText:
stopwatch durationTimer  is not thread-safe. previously we had accessed it with synchronized block which that also was not ideal.
My suggestion is to change durationTimer type as long and make it volatile.
private volatile long durationTimerMs
That way you can safely access it everywhere and we won't need synchronized block

in the new code in some places this is accessed without synchronized block that may cause potential thread-safety issue.
two options:

ideally this should become private volatile durationMs to access safely from different threads. that way we wouldn't need any synchronization block around it. (this is more preferred) as volatile is more preferred than synchronized in this case.
access this StopWatch everywhere with synchrnozied block.

timeline.bodyText:
GoneException can be retried with certain conditions, and with certain conditions it can't be retried.
I see that you coded those conditions outside and the caller of isRetryableException(exception) do the additional check.
so there for some GoneException isRetryableException(GoneEx) may return true but the code may decide to not retry. that may make the naming a bit counter-intuitive.
I wonder if we should negate the logic and call this isNotRetryableException. as for "not" case we can be certain. thougth?
not a big deal either way.

timeline.bodyText:
why do we need these two new interfaces LastRetryWithExceptionHolder, LastRetryWithExceptionProvider?
Is it to provide the linkage between the inner policies and the outer policy?
The inner class should be able to access the outer class field. RetryWithPolicy should be able to access  the GoneAndRetryWithRetryPolicy.retryWithException with GoneAndRetryWithRetryPolicy.this.retryWithException
https://www.programiz.com/java-programming/nested-inner-class
I think we should be able to get rid of the two new interfaces with above appraoch.
